Comment: It's always fascinating to see how differences in fundamental worldview drive people's reasoning.  In years past, a main idea behind secularism in schools was that it *protected* religion. Because it seems inevitable that if public resources flow to religious teachings it will advantage popular religions at the expense of minority religions. Anyone who has any political sense immediately knows that games will be played with money (as usual) and politicians who are certian *their* religion is the right one will seek to increase the money flowing to its teachings. and these debates will always flow in the direction of the popular religions or denominations and against the new and minority religions. Tensions will flame and it'll make politics even more annoying.   So to prevent this, the idea was to have schools be secular. To have no religious preferences, and to teach whatever seemed to be the scientific consensus (or was best supported with non-specificlly-religious evidence) and let specifically religious teachings get by with whatever resources they themselves can generate for their own propagation. The closest to fair we can get, given the circumstances.  And people accepted this line of reasoning. But, crucially, it relies on someone accepting that premise that secularism really is an absence (or nonpreference) of religion. A lot of modern Christians, however, reject this premise and strongly believe that secularism is actually a religious position, and one that is unfairly elevated by government policies such as this charter school rule to boot.  Now, I dont want to argue about whether secularism or atheism are religious beliefs, but I just find it interesting how this discussion can really change depending on these assumptions. Brett Kavanaugh, through his questioning, clearly seems to see it this way because otherwise it wouldn't make sense to suggest that religions are being discriminated against by rules favoring secularism.  Personally, I am conflicted. As a legal matter, I am not sure the establishment clause actually supports strict secularism in the way many seem to think it does. On the other hand, I am fairly certain the propagation of taxpayer supported religious schools (charter or otherwise) will benefit established religions *far* more than minority and new religions. Which seems unfair and contrary to the idea of a marketplace of idea.

Comment: The schools would argue that it is the family’s choice to enroll their child in their school so there isn’t any State coercion at play. I think there are limits to that in broader application but I believe this case involves a virtual school. Specific to this case, it’s hard to suggest that parents are compelled to enroll their children in a virtual school offering religious instruction.   The court has already affirmed several times that religious organizations can’t be categorically excluded from neutral public programs based on their religious status alone. The crux of this case is whether direct state funding of schools providing religious instruction and engaging in religious activities is a violation of the “establishment clause”.   In theory, I’m not sure that it is. Despite being a committed atheist, I am also a textualist and have long struggled with conventional interpretations of the establishment clause. To me, the clause is expressly prohibiting establishment of a state religion - prohibition of any neutral interactions between the state and religions in general (as indicated by traditional “separation of church and state” doctrine) is not well-grounded in the text.   However, functionally, I think there are major entanglement risks here. Do certain religions/sects have more demonstrated capacity for school/existing schools? Would granting religious schools eligibility likely lead to asymmetrical access between religions and sects? Is there a reasonable chance of one religion or sect being awarded the majority of charters? Is there risk of physical religious schools being among only few public options in rural areas, thereby introducing a new level of coercion? Is it likely that contracting decisions will become political, informed by religious affiliation/perception, and/or contingent on lobbying? Does that amount to sufficient “establishment” to be a violation of the establishment clause?

Comment: There have been cases involving churches. *Trinity Lutheran* was a case where the Court held that religious organizations couldn’t be categorically excluded from a a public grant providing renovation (via a program recycling old tires) of playground surfaces. Because the program was facially neutral and the uses secular in nature, it was held that churches couldn’t be excluded from public funding based on their religious status alone.   With evolving “free exercise” jurisprudence, it’s becoming less and less possible to apply establishment clause restrictions on private entities. An element of this case I didn’t expect to be so influential is whether Oklahoma charter schools are public actors or private entities. If they are found to be the latter, then it’s unlikely that the Court will opt for strict scrutiny of establishment claims.   I am thoroughly unconvinced that charter schools are not acting as state agents when providing K-12 education under state charter - under Oklahoma law and common sense, they surely are public actors. That does not appear to be the leaning of several current Justices.  Even so, if contracts are open to any religion or sect, we have to be specific about what constitutes “establishment”. Does the constitution prevent “establishment” of a pluralistic multi-faith (including secular) educational environment? I’m not sure it does but I’m also not convinced it doesn’t.
